statement.tex: %text If $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{1}$ and $\ora{b}=\vector{}{1}{-1}$, find a vector $\ora{c}$ such that $\ora{a}\times \ora{c}=\ora{b}$ and $\ora{a}\cdot \ora{c}=3$ %

step.context: %text If $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{1}$, $\ora{c}=\vector{x}{y}{z}$ and $\ora{a}\cdot \ora{c}=3$, is the following correct? %
step.reason:
%text Dot product of any two vectors $\ora{v_1}=\vector{a_1}{a_2}{a_3}$ and $\ora{v_2}=\vector{b_1}{b_2}{b_3}$ is given by, $\ora{v_1}\cdot\ora{v_2}=a_1a_2+b_1b_2+c_1c_3$
In the given problem, $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{1}$ and $\ora{c}=\vector{x}{y}{z}$, therefore, $\ora{a}\cdot \ora{c}=x+y+z$ and hence, $x+y+z=3$ %

step.context: %text If $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{1}$, $\ora{b}=\vector{}{1}{-1}$, $\ora{c}=\vector{x}{y}{z}$ and $\ora{a}\times \ora{c}=\ora{b}$, then is the following correct? %
step.reason: %text Vector (cross) product of any two vectors $\ora{v_1}=\vector{a_1}{a_2}{a_3}$ and $\ora{v_2}=\vector{b_1}{b_2}{b_3}$ is given by, % \ora{v_1}\times\ora{v_2}=\left\vert \begin{array}{ccc} \imath & \jmath & {\it k} \\ a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \end{array}\right\vert \\ %text In the given problem, $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{1}$, $\ora{b}=\vector{}{1}{-1}$ and $\ora{c}=\vector{x}{y}{z}$, therefore, % \therefore\ora{a}\times \ora{c}=\vector{(z-y)}{(x-z)}{(y-z)} \\ %text Using the condition $\ora{a}\times \ora{c}=\ora{b}$, % \begin{align} &\vector{(z-y)}{(x-z)}{(y-z)}=\ora{b} \\ \implies &\vector{(z-y)}{(x-z)}{(y-z)}=\vector{}{1}{-1} \\ \implies &z-y=0, x-z=1, y-x=-1 \end{align}
